paragraphs: Acupuncture derives from Latin: acus (needle) and puncture (to pierce).
With a history of ~4,000 years, it involves stimulating specific body points using fine needles.
The aim is to support a balanced flow of Qi through meridians so the body functions harmoniously as a whole.

ivfEffects.title: Effects on infertility and IVF
paragraphs: Research on acupuncture in infertility dates back to the 1990s. Some clinical approaches report that acupuncture may play a supportive role in IVF.
benefits: Supporting blood flow to uterus and ovaries.
Reducing uterine motility to aid embryo implantation.
Modulating stress response (lowering stress hormones; promoting relaxation), which may help during treatment.
Some reports suggest potential support of oocyte quality.

sideEffects.title: Side effects
paragraphs: Mild, transient pain on insertion, minor bleeding or bruising may occur; these usually resolve within a few days. Single-use sterile needles are used.

how.title: How is it applied in IVF?
paragraphs: Protocols vary across clinics and practitioners.
Often started ~1 month before IVF, continued during ovarian stimulation; additional sessions are done on embryo transfer day and shortly after.
Some protocols use two sessions on transfer day: before and after transfer.
If only one session is preferred, it is commonly done before transfer.
Points may include specific areas on the head, hands, lower abdomen, below the knee and feet. No special preparation is required.
